Award.AwardTitle: Finite Rank Perturbations and Model Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many physical systems are modeled by differential operators. One way of describing a system's long-term behavior is through spectral theory, which includes the finding of frequencies naturally exhibited by the system. Imagine a vibrating string or beam of fixed length. Clearly, its frequency (think "sound") depends on how its ends (aka boundaries) are clamped down or otherwise restricted. In general, the spectrum of a differential operator and with it the properties of a physical system can change drastically when the conditions imposed on the boundary are changed. In many cases, we know the complete spectrum for one set of boundary conditions. From there, we can gain knowledge about the system under other conditions via the theory of so-called finite rank perturbations.

The primary goal of the project is to systematically study spectral theory of finite rank unitary perturbations by tightening the relationship to corresponding functional models. The rank one setting is reasonably well-understood, while a general treatment of the finite rank problem presented several digressions. Initially, non-cyclic unitary unperturbed operators posed an issue. This problem is now resolved. The general problem involves matrix-valued Herglotz and Cauchy-type transforms. The study of these transforms as part of this project will provide insight into finite rank perturbation theory. A regularization of the so-called exterior Cauchy transform (as was done in the rank one setting) is planned. Further investigations will be made into the difficult case of infinite rank perturbations with defect operators in the trace class. The analogous self-adjoint setting, as well as concrete applications to differential operators, will also be investigated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long-term behavior of a physical system can be described through the so-called spectral theory of self-adjoint operators. The primary goal of this project was to systematically track how operators' spectra change under finite rank perturbations. Physically, such finite rank perturbations arise, e.g., when changing the boundaries of a vibrating string away from being clamped down. The theory also finds applications in systems that have degenerate states (i.e. when an eigenvalue or another part of the spectrum has higher multiplicity). Degeneracy is mathematically formulated through the 'non-cyclicity' of the operator.

In a series of papers, the PI (jointly with her co-authors) has obtained a full extension of several results that were known for rank one perturbations to the setting of higher (finite) rank perturbations, via a careful study of so-called matrix-valued Herglotz and Cauchy-type transforms. Several extended statements and proofs revealed new phenomena, such as a certain directionality of the matrix-valued spectral measure. The main reason for these differences in the proofs and statements come about from the fact that (non-commutative) matrix algebra is more involved than commutative algebra. The essence of many of our new proofs consist of an interplay between the non-commutativity and the analyticity of the matrix-valued functions involved, alongside exploiting that the background setting of finite rank perturbations provides some serious advantages when it comes to convergences.

For example, at eigenvalues, we proved the (so-called non-tangential) convergence of matrix-valued Herglotz and Cauchy-type transforms and expressed the matrix-valued Clark operator in terms of those. We derived a formula in the vein of Nevanlinna's theorem for the matrix-mass of eigenvalues. We extended the connection between Caratheodory angular derivatives and point masses of so-called Aleksandrov-Clark measures. Further, we found and proved a restriction of the location and directional properties of the so-called singular measure under perturbations. The analog result for rank one perturbations is known as the Aronszajn-Donoghue theorem. We found a general version of the Aleksandrov spectral averaging formula for finite rank perturbations.

The PI has also been involved in more explicitly changing boundary conditions of Sturm-Liouville differential operators, and in applying former mathematical research on cyclicity properties under rank one perturbations to so-called Anderson-type Hamiltonians. In the most recent paper, the underlying (unperturbed) operator is the discrete fractional Laplacian (-Δ)s. Findings show the dependence of (de-)localization behavior on the chosen fraction s.

The grant is acknowledged on 13 peer reviewed publications, including one peer reviewed survey. Many of the PI's co-authors are the PI's graduate students or otherwise junior researchers. During the NSF grant, the PI has graduated two Ph.D. students, has co-advised one more, and worked with one postdoctoral associate. Further, the PI has been working with a graduate student whom belongs to an underrepresented minority. He is also the recipient of the funds supplemental to this grant. Since this grant has been active, the PI has delivered 23 presentations related to the project, including an undergraduate seminar and many accessible to graduate students. Within the duration of the grant and beyond the standard departmental duties, the PI has co-organized 6 conferences/special sessions and served on two NSF panels.
